repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4280

This PR enables Python exceptions to be propagated by (non-extern) `cdef` functions by default. The behaviour for `extern` functions is unchanged. 

It also adds a new `noexcept` modifier that can be used to declare `cdef` functions that will not raise.

Finally, it adds to the `language-basics` and `migrating-to-cython-3.0`  parts of the documentation, describing the changes .

comment_data.body: Redundant line
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3002,9 +3002,15 @@ def p_with_gil(s):

 def p_exception_value_clause(s):
+    # the default behaviour is to always
+    # check for exceptions
+    exc_check = 1
     exc_val = None
-    exc_check = 0
-    if s.sy == 'except':

+        s.next()
+        exc_val = None

comment_data.body:
This line can now be removed (similar below).

In contrast, the `except -1` case (i.e. the as-of-now still non-existent else-branch of `if s.sy == '?'`) will need an `exc_check = 0`.

comment_data.body:
Without having checked in detail, this looks right to me.

It's 'IDENT' because it isn't specifically a reserved keyword (because you should be able to use `noexcept` as a Python variable name for example). You check for that, then you check the content. If you didn't check for `IDENT` first then I don't know if you'd be confident it has a `systring` attribute.

Not completely sure of any of this but it definitely looks reasonable on a first look.

comment_data.body:
Counts as deliberate breakage, I guess. I think the way forward is then to allow both placements for one(!) of the two modifiers already in 0.29.x, and then deprecate one of them by first making the documentation consistent.

Since `with gil`reads best at the end of the signature line (because it's similar to a `with gil:` statement inside of the function), I think we should allow `except -1 nogil`, and then newly require `noexcept nogil`, so that people get used to that order.

comment_data.body: Spurious indent here

@scoder re: your comment [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4670#discussion_r854489596), I believe this will allow placing `nogil` either before or after the exception value -- was this what you were looking for?

If we want to enable this only for Cython < 3.0, would parsing `Cython.__version__` be the right way to go about that? (I couldn't find similar examples in the codebase).

comment_data.body:
I think it's confusing that the values for `exc_check` can take `True/False/'+'`. 

`CFuncType` says this is a boolean member,
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/9341e73aceface39dd7b48bf46b3f376cde33296/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L2853-L2858

but that's not true, it's used at least here
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/9341e73aceface39dd7b48bf46b3f376cde33296/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L2988-L2992

and here
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/9341e73aceface39dd7b48bf46b3f376cde33296/Cython/Compiler/PyrexTypes.py#L3041-L3045

comment_data.body:
My 2c is that semantically `except +` is not the same as `exc_check=False, exc_val=True` (`except *` for example is also not associated with a particular exception value).

I agree that the three-value state is undesirable. Do you think this can be tackled in a separate PR instead?

comment_data.body:
I started looking at the tristate thing as a follow-up, but it looks more complicated to me than previously thought. In particular, `exc_value` can be populated even if `exc_check='+'`, so I don't see a way to get rid of the tri-state without introducing another boolean/variable, which is likely not worth it.

In the meantime, perhaps the docstring I started writing might be useful for later readers of this function (because for someone not knee-deep in cython entrails, I'd say it's not obvious 😅)

```suggestion
def p_exception_value_clause(s, ctx):
    """
    Parse exception value clause.

    Maps clauses to exc_check / exc_value as follows:
     ___________________________________________________
    |                           |           |           |
    | Clause                    | exc_check | exc_value |
    |___________________________|___________|___________|
    |                           |           |           |
    | <nothing> (default func.) | True      | None      |
    | <nothing> (cdef extern)   | False     | None      |
    | noexcept                  | False     | None      |
    | except <val>              | False     | <val>     |
    | except? <val>             | True      | <val>     |
    | except +                  | '+'       | None      |
    | except +*                 | '+'       | '*'       |
    | except +<PyErr>           | '+'       | <PyErr>   |
    |___________________________|___________|___________|
    """
    exc_val = None
```

comment_data.body:
Just realized that `except *` is a thing as well. It's somewhat confusing that this isn't something like `except? *` (as otherwise, `except?` means `check=True` and `except` means `check=False`), but it's black-on-white in the [docs](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#static-typing).

```suggestion
    | except <val>                | True       | False       | <val>       |
    | except? <val>               | True       | True        | <val>       |
    | except *                    | True       | True        | None        |
```

+Exception values and ``noexcept``
+=================================
+
+``cdef`` functions that are not ``extern`` now propagate Python
+exceptions by default, where previously they needed to explicitly be
+declated with an :ref:`exception value <error_return_values>` in order
+for them to do so. A new ``noexcept`` modifier can be used to declare
+``cdef`` functions that will not raise exceptions.
+
+In existing code, you should mainly look out for ``cdef`` functions
+that are declared without an exception value::
+
+  cdef int spam(int x):
+      pass
+
+If you left out the exception value by mistake, i.e., the function
+should propagate Python exceptions, then the new behaviour will take
+care of this for you, and correctly propagate any exceptions.
+
+On the other hand, if you didn't declare an exception value because
+you want to avoid exceptions propagating out of this function, the new behaviour
+will result in slightly less efficient code being generated.  To
+prevent that, you must declare the function explicitly as being

Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.

– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
